definitions.definition: a place with many houses, shops, etc. where people live and work. It is larger than a village but smaller than a city.

examples.text: The nearest town is ten miles away.
a university/seaside/market town
I live in a small town.
How many people live in the town?
We spent a month in the French town of Le Puy.
They live in a rough part of town.
I spent years moving from town to town.
It was built as a new town in the 1960s.
Kitzbühel is an ancient fortified town with fine medieval buildings.
She has gone back to live in her home town.
a 19th-century mill town that used to produce cotton
a busy market town
a lake just outside the town
a sleepy provincial town in southern France
a thriving holiday town
the dusty border town of Eagle Pass, Texas
the rolling hills that surround the town
the sun-drenched beach towns of Southern California
Sackville is a small university town in eastern Canada.

definitions.definition: the people who live in a particular town

examples.text: The whole town is talking about it.

definitions.definition: the area of a town where most of the shops and businesses are

examples.text: We are only five minutes from the centre of town.
Mum's in town doing some shopping.
Can you give me a lift into town?
Millie hit the town, looking for excitement.

definitions.definition: a particular town where somebody lives and works or one that has just been referred to

examples.text: I'll be in town next week if you want to meet.
This restaurant serves the best steaks in town.
He married a girl from out of town.
The gossips finally drove her out of town.
He left town yesterday for a conference in Cape Town.
I was out of town last week.
They wanted to move out of town and start a new life in the country.
They'll be back in town tomorrow.

definitions.definition: life in towns or cities as opposed to life in the country
definitions.labels: (especially North American English)(British English)(British English)(North American English)(informal)(British English, informal)North American English, informal

examples.text: Pollution is just one of the disadvantages of living in the town.
Do you prefer the town to the country?

definitions.definition: to do something with a lot of energy, enthusiasm, etc., especially by spending a lot of money

examples.text: They really went to town on the decorations for the party.

definitions.definition: a man who frequently goes to fashionable parties, clubs, theatres, etc.

examples.text: In his new suit, he looked quite the man about town.

definitions.definition: the most important thing of a particular type, or the only thing that is available
visiting restaurants, clubs, theatres, etc. for entertainment, especially at night

examples.text: a night on the town
How about going out on the town tonight?

definitions.definition: to go to a lot of different bars, clubs, etc. and enjoy yourself

wordOrigin: Old English tūn ‘enclosed piece of land, homestead, village’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch tuin ‘garden’ and German Zaun ‘fence’.
